City Council
Regular Meeting
3/2/2020 5:30 PM
Sullivan Chamber
Cambridge City Hall   795 Massachusetts Ave   Cambridge, MA 02139
Downloads:
Agenda Summary Agenda Packet
Final Actions Minutes Video
Hearing Schedule
1. HS-2017-3 : Regular City Council Meeting
Call to Order
Roll Call
Pledge of Allegiance
Submission of the Record
Public Comment
I. City Manager's Agenda
1. CMA 2020 #49 : A communication transmitted from Louis A. DePasquale, City Manager, relative to Surveillance Technology Impact Report regarding video recording devices on school buses. REPORT ACCEPTED/PLACED ON FIL

Councillor Zondervan voted "no"

City Manager's Agenda Item Printout
a. School_STIR_Bus Video_Pending 030220
2. CMA 2020 #50 : A communication transmitted from Louis A. DePasquale, City Manager, relative to a request for authorization to allow the Purchasing Agent to award a five (5) year contract to a successful bidder on the School Bus Transportation Bid. ORDER ADOPTED [Unanimous]
City Manager's Agenda Item Printout
a. School Bus contract order 030220
3. CMA 2020 #51 : A communication transmitted from Louis A. DePasquale, City Manager, relative to the appointment of new members and reappointments of the following persons as a members of the Human Services Commission for a term of three years, effective March 2, 2020. New Members: Collin Fedor, Christopher Fischer and Kathleen Kelly. Reappointments: Julie Asher, Christine Elow and Rev. Lorraine Thornhill. PLACED ON FILE
City Manager's Agenda Item Printout
4. CMA 2020 #52 : A communication transmitted from Louis A. DePasquale, City Manager, relative to the Harvard Square Conservation District Study Committee report. REFERRED TO COMMITTEE

Ordinance committee

City Manager's Agenda Item Printout
a. HSqCD cover from CSullivan 022420
b. Harvard Square Conservation District Study Committee report 022420
5. CMA 2020 #53 : A communication transmitted from Louis A. DePasquale, City Manager, relative to Awaiting Report Item Number 19-157, regarding the Cambridge Police Department Procedural Justice Dashboard. PLACED ON FILE
City Manager's Agenda Item Printout
a. CPD Dashboard 030220
6. CMA 2020 #54 : Transmitting Communication from Louis A. DePasquale, City Manager, relative to the appropriation of $15,000,000 from Free Cash to the Affordable Housing Trust to assist in preserving affordability of units at Fresh Pond Apartments at 362 and 364 Rindge Avenue. ORDER ADOPTED [Unanimous]
City Manager's Agenda Item Printout
a. Fresh Pond apartments order
7. CMA 2020 #55 : A communication transmitted from Louis A. DePasquale, City Manager, relative to the City of Cambridge retaining its AAA rating from the nation's three major credit rating agencies. PLACED ON FILE
City Manager's Agenda Item Printout
a. Moody's report 030220
b. S&P report 030220
c. Fitch report 030220
8. CMA 2020 #56 : A communication transmitted from Louis A. DePasquale, City Manager, relative to an update on the proposed Eversource substation on Fulkerson Street. PLACED ON FILE
City Manager's Agenda Item Printout
a. Eversource substation update attachments 030220
II. Calendar
On the Table
1. POR 2019 #339 : That the City Manager is requested to direct the City Solicitor, Community Development, Public Works, Inspectional Services and any other related departments to review the proposed amendments regarding the prohibition of Natural Gas Infrastructure in New Buildings. TABLED ON JANUARY 27, 2020 NO ACTION TAKEN
Policy Order Printout
a. Ban on Fracked Gas Infrastructure language
2. COF 2020 #14 : A communication was received from City Clerk, Anthony I. Wilson, transmitting a compilation of the Surveillance technology Impact Reports tabled by the City Council on February 24, 2020. PLACED ON FILE
Communication and Report from Other City Officers Printout
a. Surveillance Technology Impact reports regarding Bus Video Recorders
Unfinished Business
3. CMA 2018 #286 : A communication transmitted from Louis A. DePasquale, City Manager, relative to Awaiting Report Item Number 18-108, regarding a report on offering early voting in City Council and School Committee Elections. NO ACTION TAKEN

PENDING RESPONSE FROM LEGISLATURE

AS OF JUNE 21, 2021 NOT ACTED ON BY LEGISLATURE

City Manager's Agenda Item Printout
a. Early Voting Municipal Elections 11-05-18
b. Early Voting Municipal Elections RL 11-05-18
c. Early Voting Petition Order 110518
4. APP 2019 #80 : A Zoning Petition Has been received from Suzanne P. Blier regarding Harvard Square Zoning Petition. Ordained [Unanimous]

Motion by Councillor McGovern to delete the words '4.35o (Fast Order Food Establishment)' from section 20.54.3(1)(k). Passed by voice vote of nine members.

Application and Petitions Printout
a. Harvard Sq. Zoning_10.7.2019
b. Harvard Square petition with proposed amendments by the Ordinance Committee on Janury 30, 2020
5. APP 2019 #82 : A refilling Zoning Petition Has been received from Joseph T. Maguire of Alexandria Real Estate Equities, Inc. transmitting a proposed revised amendment to the zoning ordinance by creating the Grand Junction Pathway Overlay District. Ordained [Unanimous]

Motion by Vice Mayor Mallon to amend sections 20.1011 and 20.1013 to delete the words "______, 2019" in both section and insert the words "March 2, 2020". The motion passed by voice vote of nine members.

Application and Petitions Printout
a. Refile_APP_Alexandria_10.21.2019
b. 200210.Alexandria Grand Junction (refiled petition)_First Publication #3531
6. POR 2019 #387 : That section 11.202(b) of Article 11.000, entitled SPECIAL REGULATIONS, of the Zoning Ordinance of the City of Cambridge, be amended the table as follows: January 28, 2020 (Annual Adjustment) $19.10 per square foot PASSED TO A SECOND READING ON FEBRUARY 24, 2020, TO BE ORDAINED ON OR AFTER MARCH 8, 2020. NO ACTION TAKEN
Policy Order Printout
a. proposed amendments to incentive zoning petition from the ordinance commitee
b. 200224.Special Regulations - Amend Section 11.202(b) - First Publication #3533

Policy Order Printout
5. POR 2020 #46 : That the City Manager be and hereby is requested to direct staff to begin including a Racial Equity Impact Statement on all relevant agenda items including, but not limited to, appointments, appropriations, ordinances, legal opinions, policies, procedures and regulations, beginning on March 9, 2020. Order Adopted as Amended

BY AN AFFIRMATIVE VOTE OF NINE MEMBERS

Policy Order Printout

Policy Order Printout

Policy Order Printout
VII. Communications and Reports from Other City Officers
1. COF 2020 #15 : A communication was received from Mayor Sumbul Siddiqui, transmitting information regarding preserving the affordability of the Fresh Pond Apartments. PLACED ON FILE
Communication and Report from Other City Officers Printout
a. Fresh Pond Apartments Communication_Feb 27 2020
b. FPA Expiring Use Info Sheet_2.24.2020
Appended Information
Awaiting Report List
1. AR-16-101 : Report on the potential of building below market rental housing on City-owned parking lots along Bishop Allen Drive. On a communication from Councillor McGovern requesting that this matter be forwarded to the 2018-2019 Legislative Session.
2. AR-16-108 : Report on whether people displaced and qualify for Emergency Status who are using Section 8 in other cities or towns can retain their resident preference for the purpose of Inclusionary Housing. On a communication from Councillor Kelley requesting that this matter be forwarded to the 2018-2019 Legislative Session.
3. AR-18-38 : Report on inventory of all City-owned vacant buildings and lots and the City's plans for them, if any.
4. AR-18-60 : Report on a small business parking pilot that would allow temporary on-street employee parking during typical daytime operating hours.
5. AR-18-66 : Report on establishing a Young Adult Civic Unity Committee to be modeled after the Citizen Civic Unity Committee and to recruit applicants from all across the community and across all socio-economic backgrounds.
6. AR-18-73 : Report on establishing and implementing a dynamic new initiative that will seek to place Port residents (ages 18 and over) on paths to jobs with family-sustaining wages.
7. AR-18-119 : Report on evaluating the existing capacity of fire stations in the Kendall Square area and whether a new fire station is needed, and if so, determining the feasibility of locating a plot of land for this use.
8. AR-19-3 : Report on establishing a Central Square Improvement Fund and allocate no less than 25% of funds generated to the arts.
9. AR-19-21 : Report on the process for establishing a formal, thorough review of the Citys Affordable Home Ownership programs, incorporating a plan for obtaining and analyzing substantial quantitative data inclusive of all types of units.
10. AR-19-22 : Report on the feasibility of allowing small businesses to host live acoustic music performances without a license, and if feasible, present the City Council with a proposal to allow such performances.
11. AR-19-45 : Report on compiling a full accounting of streets, schools, and public buildings that may be named in honor of those who have ties to the American slave trade, and to work towards renaming all of these streets, schools, and buildings.
12. AR-19-49 : Report on recommending restrictions on signage specific to retail establishments that sell e-cigarettes and other vaping devices.
13. AR-19-58 : Report on working with the Recycling Advisory Committee and other stakeholders to draft an ordinance banning single-use plastic items in Cambridge.
14. AR-19-62 : Report on drafting a formal Anti-bias /Cultural Competency Strategic Plan for eventual adoption and implementation.
15. AR-19-66 : Report on whether it is possible to reduce or eliminate Building Permit Fees for 100% affordable housing development projects, through an exemption or other means and investigate what types of real estate tax abatements are possible for 100% affordable housing moving forward.
16. AR-19-74 : Report on establishing a working committee to review the monuments, memorials, and markers throughout Cambridge to determine whether any of these commemorate those who were linked to the slave trade or engaged in other similarly shameful acts and to determine which individuals should be newly recognized with a monument, memorial, or marker.
17. AR-19-75 : Report on exploring the feasibility of partnering with a local research institution to conduct a study that determines how many ridehail vehicles are on the roads during both on and off-peak times and their impacts on congestion and safety.
18. AR-19-86 : Report on developing a Vacant Storefront Registration Policy.
19. AR-19-100 : Report on the feasibility of implementing an additional regulatory requirement for listing a registration/license number for Short-Term Rentals.
20. AR-19-106 : Report on conducting City directed environmental testing on the Sullivan Courthouse building and water in basement, to determine the risk posed to the public, and provide a timeline of completion and to establish an operational understanding directly with DCAMM officials and ask for a state designee for communication/coordination on how the building will be secured and monitored.
21. AR-19-123 : Report on the feasibility of closing some portion of Harvard Square to vehicular traffic on a select number of days during the summer of 2020 to have open market-style events.
22. AR-19-127 : Report on instituting regularly scheduled public conversations between Public Utilities' representatives from Eversource, the Water Dept. Comcast, Verizon and any other appropriate entities to keep the City and public informed.
23. AR-19-130 : Report on requesting to allocate more funds in the FY21 budget for the small business improvement grants and to confer with the Massachusetts Attorney Generals office on whether other cities in Massachusetts have been facing similar issues with ADA compliance and what can be done to protect the small businesses.
24. AR-19-132 : Report on planting new trees in Magazine Beach Park in the Spring of 2020 with a special focus on the eastern end of the park and the grove area.
25. AR-19-134 : Report on increasing funding to the Citys HomeBridge program so that access to homeownership may be made available to a wider range of incomes, as the program intends.
26. AR-19-137 : Report on determining if ISD can be given the authority to issue citations for smoking in non-smoking buildings and to report back to the City Council.
27. AR-19-139 : Report on determining whether it would be possible to allow a permitted area for serving alcoholic beverages on Danehy Park property during special community-wide events.
28. AR-19-141 : Report on looking into the idea of hiring a social worker in the FY2021 budget for the Central Square Library branch.
29. AR-19-142 : Report on determining the feasibility of expediting the Demolition and Rebuilding permitting process in the event of a natural disaster.
30. AR-19-144 : Report on determining the feasibility of instituting and funding a Fire Cadet Program.
31. AR-19-145 : Report on reviewing all the Citys policies and procedures related to the procurement, installation and disposal of artificial turf.
32. AR-19-147 : Report on installing hearing loop technology inside the Sullivan Chamber as part of the upcoming renovations to City Hall, and in other critical City meeting venues wherever possible and other accessibility improvements.
33. AR-19-151 : Report on the feasibility of making Porter Square and Massachusetts Avenue between Roseland Street and Beech Street a quick-build Complete Street with bus priority.
34. AR-19-153 : Report on plans designed to mitigate the impact of the closing of Windsor House upon Cambridge seniors.
35. AR-19-157 : Report on providing an update of when the public Police Dashboard will be fully operational. REPORT RECEIVED AND ACCEPTED
36. AR-20-1 : Report on the work that has been done to Support Small Business and the Arts through Tourism.
37. AR-20-3 : Report on determining the feasibility of purchasing sensory bags for Police vehicles as a pilot program and report back to council for FY21 Budget.
38. AR-20-4 : Report on the feasibility of instituting and funding a fare-free pilot bus program.
39. AR-20-5 : Report on the potential for implementing sufficient traffic-calming solutions on Upton Street.
40. AR-20-6 : Report on the acquisition and implementation of interpretation services for City Council meetings and other public City meetings.
41. AR-20-7 : Report on reviewing the roles, responsibilities, and compensation of City Council Aides with an eye toward designating this as a full-time position.
42. AR-20-8 : Report on working with the residents in the vicinity of Eustis Street to implement traffic calming measures on this street.
43. AR-20-9 : Report on allocating the necessary funds, and develop a comprehensive public safety plan, including contingency plans so that the event can take place in a secure time and place, even in the presence of significant threats that can be anticipated.
44. AR-20-10 : Report on renaming the Agassiz neighborhood.
45. AR-20-11 : Report on the process for renaming the maintenance area within the Ryan Garage at 147 Hampshire Street in honor of Sydney Cox, with this becoming known as the Sydney James Cox Maintenance Facility.
46. AR-20-12 : Report on the feasibility of instituting a program to install rings on parking meters to expand bicycle parking options.
47. AR-20-13 : Report on expanding the Head Start program hours and adding additional scholarships to improve access to high-quality, early childhood educational resources.
48. AR-20-15 : Report on the feasibility of limiting the number of Saturdays and holidays any one developer can be permitted for any one construction project.
49. AR-20-16 : Report on the feasibility of eliminating Library fines.
50. AR-20-17 : Report on adding lighting and implementing an appropriate shut down time to the plan for Glacken Field.
51. AR-20-18 : Report on the feasibility of implementing additional dedicated bus lanes, as well as fully separate protected bicycle lanes.
52. AR-20-19 : Report on producing a Request For Proposal for the municipal broadband feasibility study that was called for by the City's Broadband Task Force in August 2016.
Adjournment
